topic.title: Backup and restore Docker persistent volumes

body.p: In order to restore a Docker volume, you need to restore a special VM that has been deployed for the sole purpose of backing up Docker volumes. There is one such VM for each datastore defined in the datastores array in the group_vars/vars file. By default, a single datastore is specified in the playbooks:
body.note: The use of a single datastore is recommended. If you have configured multiple datastores, you need to understand and keep track of how your Docker volumes are distributed across the datastores.
body.p: The name of the special VM follows the pattern <prefix>-in-dockervols-<Datastore> where:

ul.li: <prefix> is the value of the variable dummy_vm_prefix from the file group_vars/vars
<Datastore> is the name of the datastore

body.p: For example, based on the default values in the scripts, the VM name would be hpe-VM-in-dockervols-Docker_HPE

section.title: Create a Docker volume
section.p: To see any existing Docker volumes created using the vSphere driver, use the docker volume ls command and limit the results to those volumes created using the vSphere driver. If you have already used the playbooks to install Prometheus for example, you may see a listing as follows:
section.codeblock: # docker volume ls | grep vsphere vsphere:latest prom_hpe-db-data@Docker_HPE
section.p: To create a Docker volume named test_01, you can use the docker volume create command specifying the vSphere driver:
section.codeblock: # docker volume create -d vsphere test_01 test_01
section.p: You can check that the volume exists using the docker volume ls command:
section.codeblock: # docker volume ls | grep vsphere vsphere:latest prom_hpe-db-data@Docker_CLH vsphere:latest test_01@Docker_CLH
section.p: You can attach a container to the volume and then add data to it by creating a text file with some arbitrary content:
section.codeblock: # docker run -it --rm -v test_01:/tmp alpine sh -c "echo some test data here > /tmp/foo.txt"
section.p: If this is the first time you have used the alpine image, you may see additional output relating to download of image layers:
section.codeblock: Unable to find image 'alpine:latest' locally latest: Pulling from library/alpine 88286f41530e: Already exists Digest: sha256:f006ecbb824d87947d0b51ab8488634bf69fe4094959d935c0c103f4820a417d Status: Downloaded newer image for alpine:latest
section.p: The container will exit once the shell command has run and any unnamed volumes will be removed. However, the named volume test_01:/tmp will persist. To check that the data is still available after the container exited, spin up a new container and try to retrieve the data:
section.codeblock: # docker run -it --rm -v test_01:/tmp alpine sh -c "cat /tmp/foo.txt" some test data here

section.title: Automated backup
section.p: By default, the special VM and any Docker volume in the dockvols folder are backed up every hour. This is controlled by the following settings in the group_vars/vars file.
section.codeblock:
backup_policies: - name: 'hpe-gold' days: 'All' start_time: '00:00' frequency: '60' retention: '43200'
dummy_vm_prefix: 'hpe-VM'
docker_volumes_policy: 'hpe-gold'
section.p: The backup policy hpe-gold is assigned to the special VM that is used to back up the Docker volumes. This policy specifies that a backup is taken every hour (frequency: '60' means sixty minutes) while the backup is retained for one month (retention: '43200' means 43200 minutes or thirty days).

section.title: Manual backup
section.p: Rather than waiting for an automated backup to take place, you can create a backup immediately. Right-click on the special VM, in this case hpe-VM-in-dockervols-Docker_HPE, select All Actions and choose Backup Virtual Machine as shown in .
You can specify a backup name, in this case manual_backup_test_01, as shown in .

section.title: Restore
section.p: Right-click on the special VM, in this case hpe-VM-in-dockervols-Docker_HPE. On the Configure tab, select Search Backups as shown in .

You can narrow the search based on the time of the backup. If you are restoring from an automatic backup, the name will be the timestamp of the backup. If you are restoring from a manual backup, the name will be the one you specified earlier when creating the backup, in this case manual_backup_test_01.
Right-click on the backup you wish to restore, as shown in , and select Restore Virtual Machine.
In the details screen, shown in , you can choose a name for the new virtual machine and specify the datastore.

The name of the new virtual machine will default to a combination of the special VM name and a timestamp, in this instance hpe-VM-in-dockervols-Docker_HPE-2018-11-26-20h47m01s. The datastore should be the one specified in the datastores array from the group_vars/vars file. Click OK to restore the virtual machine.
Once the virtual machine has been restored, navigate to the datastore and locate the new VM in the file browser, as shown in .

Navigate to the folder named 1111111-1111-1111-1111-... as shown in . You will see files with names based on the Docker volume name that you used at the start, in this instance test_01.vmdk and test_01-478...f1f.vmfd
You need to move these two files to the dockvols sub-directory named 1111111-1111-1111-1111-... in the same datastore. Right click on the .vmdk file and choose Move to... as shown in .
Set the destination folder to the dockvols sub-directory named 1111111-1111-1111-1111-... as shown in .
It is only necessary to move the .vmdk file as the .vmfd file will automatically follow. The dockvols sub-directory named 1111111-1111-1111-1111-... should now contain both files as shown in .

section.title: Test the restore
section.p: You can check that the volume test_01 has been restored by using the docker volume ls command again.
section.codeblock: # docker volume ls | grep vsphere vsphere:latest prom_hpe-db-data@Docker_HPE vsphere:latest test_01@Docker_HPE
section.p: You can verify that the volume contains the correct data by spinning up a container and running a shell command:
section.codeblock: # docker run -it --rm -v test_01:/tmp alpine sh -c "cat /tmp/foo.txt" some test data here
section.p: The data you entered in the text file before performing the backup and deleting the volume is available once again after restoring the volume.
